This was regular- ly paid till the Athenian war; but, that war being then made a pretence of its discontinuance, the Eleans would have exacted it by force. The others had recourse to the Laced monians. The dispute was referred to the Laced monian arbitration i but the Eleans, taking up a suspicion that they should not have justice, would not abide the reference, but began to ravage the territory of the Lapreat . The Laced monians, notwithstand- ing this, proceeded to a sentence: that" theLeprea- t were masters of their own conduct, and that the"Eleans were guilty of injustice;" and, as the latter would not abide by their arbitration, they threw a gar- rison of heavy-armed into Lepreum; but the Eleans, regarding this step as the reception of a city by the La- ced monians which had revolted from them, and alled- ging the treaty in which it was stipulated, that,"of"whatever places the parties were possessed upon the*' commencement of the Attic war, the same they"should continue to hold at its expiration," as if they had met with injustice, they revolt to the Argives; and the Eleans entered into that league offensive and defen- iive as hath been already related. The Corinthians soon followed their example, and, with the Calcideans, also of Thrace, became the allies of Argos. But the B otians and Megareans, though they had threatened the same thing, thought proper to drop it. They had been ill used by the Laced mo^ nians, but judged however that the democracy of the Argives would be less compatible with their interests, whose form of government was oligarchical, than the polity of the Laced monians.
